key.comment: The company or organization that provides this operating system.
Common values would be SuSE, Debian, CetnOS, Microsoft, etc.
The simple name of this OS. Could be "OpenBSD", "Windows", etc
A name for whom the system looks like.
This is the most important key since it provides the hint about the filesystem layout, packaging naming conventions, etc
Could be "redhat" for RHEL, CentOS, Fedora, Mandriva, Whitebox, Scientific Linux, etc.
"debian" for Debian, Ubuntu, KUbuntu and all Debian-derived distro's
"BSD" for all *BSD systems
"suse" for SLES, OpenSuSE and Novell Linux Desktop
Or "slackware", "aix", "solaris" etc for other systems
A nice human readable system name.
An internal name that providers use to give to their products.
Could be "Potato" for Debian, "Vista" for Windows, etc.
The edition of this OS. Common values are "Home Edition", "ES", "WS", Professional, etc
The version of this OS.
Could be "95" or "2000" for popular Windows versions, "7.3" for old Red Hat versions, etc.
The update or patch level of a system. Could be "SP3" for Windows systems, etc.
The platform this OS is installed on. Popular names are "x86_64", "ppc", "s390", "s390x", "sparc", "ia64".
Some URL the provider wants to be published.
The current hostname.
The hostid as from the `hostid` command.
